name: Sodium Valproate
summary: Sodium valproate is an anticonvulsant and mood stabilizer used in the treatment of epilepsy, bipolar disorder, and migraine prophylaxis.
description: Sodium valproate is the sodium salt of valproic acid, used widely as an antiepileptic and mood stabilizer. It is indicated for a range of seizure types, including generalized, focal, and absence seizures, as well as for acute mania in bipolar disorder and migraine prophylaxis. Its mechanism involves increasing gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) levels in the brain, modulating voltage-gated sodium channels, and inhibiting T-type calcium channels. Sodium valproate can be administered orally or intravenously.

contraindications: Hepatic disease or significant hepatic dysfunction
Pregnancy for migraine prophylaxis (due to teratogenicity)

items: Acute manic or mixed episodes in bipolar disorder

sections.text: Increases GABA concentrations in the brain by inhibiting GABA degradation and enhancing synthesis; modulates voltage-gated sodium channels; inhibits T-type calcium channels.

adult.oral: Initial: 600 mg/day in divided doses; increase by 200 mg every 3 days as needed to a usual maintenance dose of 1,000–2,000 mg/day (max 2,500 mg/day). Adjust to achieve serum levels of 50–100 mcg/mL for epilepsy and 50–125 mcg/mL for mania.

pediatric.oral: 10–15 mg/kg/day in divided doses; increase by 5–10 mg/kg/week to a usual maintenance range of 20–60 mg/kg/day.

sections.text: Seizure control may be seen within days; mood stabilization may take 1–2 weeks; migraine prophylaxis may require several weeks.

other: Black box warning: hepatotoxicity, especially in children under 2 years
Black box warning: teratogenicity—contraindicated in pregnancy for migraine prophylaxis
May increase ammonia levels—monitor especially if lethargy or vomiting occur

items.risk: Increased lamotrigine concentration and risk of rash

sections.pregnancy: Contraindicated for migraine prophylaxis; for epilepsy or bipolar disorder, use only if no alternatives are suitable due to high teratogenic risk
sections.lactation: Excreted in breast milk; use with caution and monitor infant
sections.geriatrics: Use lowest effective dose; monitor for sedation and hepatotoxicity

sections.text: Gradual dose reduction over weeks is recommended to reduce the risk of seizure recurrence or mood relapse.

items: Therapeutic serum range: 50–100 mcg/mL for epilepsy; 50–125 mcg/mL for mania
Available in oral and IV forms for acute or maintenance therapy
May be used in status epilepticus when IV formulation is available
